Description: Bronze lamp with a swing-handle: the lamp has an elongated body and a long splayed and fluked nozzle with a rounded tip and a semicircular wick-hole. The sunken upper surface is within a double rim around the body and nozzle. There is a small hole in the tip of the nozzle. The irregular filling-hole is shaped like an ivy-leaf or bunch of grapes, with indications of an incuse stem above; there is a groove in the nozzle-channel. At the rear is a curved handle of semicircular section, terminating in a calyx from which emerges a goose's head. A small hole is pierced in the edge of the calyx, with part of a chain-link remaining. The flat base follows the shape of the lamp. On each side of the lamp is a tapering lug, on which the lamp swings in the handle. The handle consists of a U-shaped stirrup terminating in duck-head loops and engraved with a vine-scroll and ivy-leaves. On one arm of the U is a ring holding a chain and pin. The stirrup is held by a lotus flower, from which extends a long tapering octagonal hook-and-spike with a double collar; below this is a hook with a duck-head terminal.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: The lamp and handle were probably made at the same time.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q3678)
